subject.topcClas: Weights and subsample selection Variables -- PERSON

stdyInfo.notes: Additional notes on a sample that is part of this study: India 2015 Births Density of the full data file: 1.0% Density of this extract: 1.0%

useStmt.citReq:
Publications and research reports based on the IPUMS-DHS database must cite it appropriately. The citation should include the following:
Elizabeth Heger Boyle, Miriam King and Matthew Sobek. IPUMS-Demographic and Health Surveys: Version 9 [dataset]. IPUMS and ICF, 2022. https://doi.org/10.18128/D080.V9
The licensing agreement for use of IPUMS-DHS data requires that users supply us with the title and full citation for any publications, research reports, or educational materials making use of the data or documentation. Please add your citation to the IPUMS bibliography at http://bibliography.ipums.org/.
useStmt.conditions: Users of IPUMS-DHS data must agree to abide by the access restrictions and terms of use set forth by the DHS Program: https://dhsprogram.com/data/Access-Instructions.cfm
useStmt.disclaimer: The user of the data acknowledges that the original collector of the data, the authorized distributor of the data, and the relevant funding agency bear no responsibility for use of the data or for interpretations or inferences based upon such uses.

stdyDscr.notes: User-provided description: Revision of (The research tends to examine the different aspects of poverty in India. So, I want to compute multidimensional poverty index based on this. Mostly I'll need data on dirt floor, electricity, children's malnourishment, education level, fuel, etc. I want to start with computing MPI by giving equal weightage to economical poverty, health and education. Then we will subdivide it. which measure of poverty ratio will be applied that I have not decided yet. I also need toc check whether for education and health I can aggregate individual data into household data.)
This extract is a revision of the user's previous extract, ID 15136799.

fileTxt.filePlac: IPUMS, 50 Willey Hall, 225 - 19th Avenue South, Minneapolis, MN 55455

var.name: SAMPLE
var.labl: IPUMS-DHS sample identifier
var.txt:
SAMPLE identifies the DHS sample from which the case is drawn. Each sample receives a unique 5-digit code. The first three digits are ISO/UN codes used in COUNTRY, and the last two digits identify the sample within the country, ordered by survey year.
The related variable SAMPLESTR is a string variable that identifies the DHS sample with the same 5-digit code.

var.name: SAMPLESTR
var.labl: IPUMS-DHS sample identifier (string)
var.txt:
SAMPLESTR is a string variable that identifies the DHS sample from which the case is drawn. Each sample receives a unique 5-digit code. The first three digits are ISO/UN codes used in COUNTRY, and the last two digits identify the sample within the country, ordered by survey year.
The related variable SAMPLE is a numeric variable that identifies the DHS sample with the same 5-digit code.

var.name: COUNTRY
var.labl: Country
var.txt: COUNTRY reports the country where the survey was fielded. The codes assigned to each country are those used by the UN Statistics Division and the ISO (International Organization for Standardization).

var.name: YEAR
var.labl: Year of sample
var.txt: YEAR reports the year when the survey was fielded, as a four-digit variable. In some cases, the DHS was conducted over the course of two years (e.g., Ethiopia 2010-2011), but YEAR always gives a single year. For full information about the timing of the surveys, please consult the IPUMS-DHS Sample Descriptions page.

var.name: IDHSPID
var.labl: Unique cross-sample respondent identifier
var.txt: IDHSPID is an identifying number unique to person in a given sample. It is a concatenation of SAMPLE and CASEID.

var.name: IDHSHID
var.labl: Unique cross-sample household identifier
var.txt: IDHSHID is an identifying number unique to a specific household in a given sample. It is a concatenation of SAMPLE, CLUSTERNO and HHNUM.

var.name: DHSID
var.labl: Key to link DHS clusters to context data (string)
var.txt: DHSID is the 14-character DHS identification code for DHS clusters constructed from the 2-character country code, the 4-digit survey year, and the 8-digit cluster identification number. DHSID is available for every IPUMS-DHS sample and uniquely identifies clusters across samples. It serves as the unique linking key between IPUMS-DHS microdata and DHS cluster shapefiles.

var.name: IDHSPSU
var.labl: Unique sample-case PSU identifier
var.txt: IDHSPSU is an identifying number unique to the primary sampling unit in a given sample. This variable is a concatenation of SAMPLE (which uniquely identifies each country- and year-specific sample) and PSU (the numbered primary sampling units within a given sample).

var.name: IDHSSTRATA
var.labl: Unique cross-sample sampling strata
var.txt:
IDHSSTRATA is an identifying number unique to the sampling strata in a given sample. This variable is a concatenation of SAMPLE (which uniquely identifies each country- and year-specific sample) and STRATA (groups of geographically similar areas, from which primary sampling units are drawn).
The variable STRATA, and hence IDHSSTRATA, are unavailable for samples from DHS Phase 1 (prior to 1990).

var.name: CASEID
var.labl: Sample-specific respondent identifier
var.txt:
CASEID is the unique identifier for each woman in a given sample year. Using CASEID and CLUSTERNO, analysts can link IPUMS-DHS data to the original DHS datasets to attach variables that are not currently available in IPUMS-DHS. For example, researchers can use CASEID and CLUSTERNO to link variables from the IPUMS-DHS with other variables from the Woman's Recode file to merge country-specific variables, or to the Household or Couples Recode file to attach variables that are not yet part of IPUMS-DHS.
In most samples, users can identify women who are in the same household by using the first 12 characters of CASEID (and CLUSTERNO (V001)), as this indicates a unique household identifier.
CASEID is generally created by The DHS Program using the variables CLUSTERNO (V001), HHNUM (V002), and LINENO (V003), with the last three characters indicating the respondent's line number in the household file.
For instructions on how to create links between IPUMS-DHS data and DHS source data, see the User Note on "Merging IDHS and DHS Data."

var.name: HHID
var.labl: Sample-specific household identifier
var.txt: HHID is an identifying number unique to each household in a given sample.

var.name: PSU
var.labl: Sample-specific primary sampling unit
var.txt:
PSU (V021) is the variable indicating the primary sampling unit or PSU. It should be used along with the variable DOMAIN (V023) to account for the impact of the sample design clustering on the variance estimates and standard errors.
The DHS Recode Manuals for Phase 2 forward describe this variable as follows:
Primary sampling unit is a number assigned to sample points to identify the primary sampling units for use in the calculation of sampling errors. This variable is usually the same as the cluster number and/or the ultimate area unit, but may differ if the sample design required a multistage selection process.See the notes on DHS webpage "Using sample weights" on variance estimation for additional information.

var.name: STRATA
var.labl: Sample-specific sampling strata
var.txt:
STRATA (V022) defines the pairings or groupings of primary sampling units used in the calculation of sampling errors when using the Taylor series expansion method.
In two-stage sampling, The DHS Program may first group small geographic areas, such as enumeration areas from the last census, into broad strata defined jointly by region and urban versus rural areas within a region. In the second stage of sampling, a subset of geographic areas (sample clusters) are selected as the sites for interviewing from within defined strata.
STRATA is not the same as DOMAIN (V023). (Domains represent statistically representative areas for which valid summary statistics can be calculated for a survey, such as provinces and national urban versus rural combined areas, as described in the survey's final report.) The DHS Program recommends using STRATA along with the variable PSU (V021) to account for the impact of the sample design clustering on the estimates of variance and standard errors.
When pooling samples, users are advised to use IDHSSTRATA, which provides a unique numeric value for each stratum across all samples. IDHSSTRATA concatenates the variables SAMPLE and STRATA.
For information on using the STRATA variable to control for complex sample design, consult the latest Guide to DHS Statistics at The DHS Program website.

var.name: DOMAIN
var.labl: Sample-specific domain
var.txt:
DOMAIN (V023) defines the basic geographic units for which the sample was designed to yield representative estimates.
The DHS Recode Manual describes DOMAIN as follows:
For example, if the sample was designed to be self-weighting within region, this variable would define those regions; if the sample was designed to be self-weighting within major urban areas, other urban areas and rural areas, this variable would define the major urban, other urban and rural areas. If the sample is self-weighted at the national level, this variable is code 0.When national estimates are desired, users should include survey design variables, including DOMAIN (V023) and PSU (V021), and the correct sample weights (e.g., PERWEIGHT (V005)) to adjust sampling errors to account for DHS' sample design.
In most countries, DOMAIN defines the stratification for the sample (generally either regional or national). However, some countries use two levels of stratification, such as region and urban/rural areas. Users should check for the correct stratification design by consulting the Final Report(s) for the sample(s) of interest (particularly the Introduction and Sample Design sections and Implementation Appendix).

var.name: HHNUM
var.labl: Household number in cluster
var.txt:
HHNUM (V002) is the number identifying the household in which the respondent was interviewed, within each sample.
To identify unique households in most samples, researchers must use HHNUM with CLUSTERNO (V001).
For most samples, HHNUM and CLUSTERNO can be used to merge IPUMS-DHS data from the women's file to DHS Household Recode files, to incorporate household variables not yet available in the IPUMS-DHS. However, in some household files, HHNUM and CLUSTERNO do not uniquely identify households in the DHS Household Recode file.
For information about the IPUMS-DHS samples where HHNUM and CLUSTERNO are not sufficient to uniquely identify households, and for guidance on what further steps to take for linking files in such cases, please consult the User Note on Linking.

var.name: CLUSTERNO
var.labl: Sample-specific cluster number
var.txt:
CLUSTERNO (V001) reports the cluster number for the person's de facto residence.
According to the DHS Sampling Manual, "A cluster is the smallest geographical survey statistical unit for DHS surveys. It consists of a number of adjacent households in a geographical area. For DHS surveys, a cluster corresponds either to an [enumeration area], or a segment of a large [enumeration area]." The most recent census for a country, which divided all territory into enumeration areas to ensure full coverage of the population, often provides the sampling frame for a DHS survey.
CLUSTERNO is the variable indicating the primary sampling unit or PSU. It should be used along with the variable STRATA to account for the impact of the sample design clustering on the estimates of variance and standard errors.
See the notes on DHS webpage "Use sample weights" on variance estimation for additional information.
CLUSTERNO (V001) and HHNUM (V002) can be used to merge the women's individual recode file to the household recode file. See the DHS webpage Merging Datasets on variables to be used for linking data sets.

var.name: ULTAREAUNIT
var.labl: Sample-specific ultimate area unit
var.txt:
ULTAREAUNIT (V004) reports the ultimate area unit for the person's de facto residence.
According to the DHS recode manuals, ULTAREAUNIT is a number assigned to each sample point to identify the ultimate area units in the collection of data. It is usually the same as the cluster number [CLUSTERNO (V001)], but may be a sequentially numbered variable for samples with a more complicated structure.ULTAREAUNIT can be used to account for the impact of the sampling design clustering on the variance estimates and standard errors.

var.name: LINENO
var.labl: Household line number of woman respondent
var.txt: LINENO (V003) reports the number of the line on which the DHS interviewer recorded the woman's name, when filling out the household schedule. After asking "Please give me the names of the persons who usually live in your household or are staying with you now, starting with the head of the household," the interviewer recorded each name in turn on successively numbered lines printed on the household survey form.

var.name: LINENOHHRESP
var.labl: Respondent's line number (answering Household questionnaire)
var.txt: LINENOHHRESP (HV003) reports the line number in the household schedule of the person responding to the questions asked in the household questionnaire. If nobody in the household was available for the interview, this variable is coded "00."

var.name: LINENOHUS
var.labl: Household line number of respondent's husband
var.txt: LINENOHUS (V034) reports the number of the line on which the DHS interviewer recorded the name of the women's husband/partner, when filling out the household schedule. After asking "Please give me the names of the persons who usually live in your household or are staying with you now, starting with the head of the household," the interviewer recorded each name in turn on successively numbered lines printed on the household survey form.

var.name: BIDX
var.labl: Birth history index number
var.txt:
BIDX reports the index number of the child in the mother's birth history, from 1 to n, where the nth birth is the mother's first birth, and 1 is the most recently born child. Up to 20 births could be reported by a woman. After asking "Now I would like to record the names of all your births, whether still alive or not, with the first one you had," the interviewer recorded each child's name in turn on successively numbered lines printed in the "Reproduction" section of the individual woman's questionnaire.
Combined with CASEID, BIDX uniquely identifies children within a sample. Combined with IDHSPID, BIDX uniquely identifies children across samples. Using these variables, data users can link IPUMS-DHS data to original DHS child-level and birth-level datasets.

var.name: PERWEIGHT
var.labl: Sample weight for persons
var.txt:
PERWEIGHT (V005) is an 8-digit variable with 6 implied decimal places, which should be used as a weighting factor to produce representative numbers accurately describing the surveyed population.
While the DHS Recode Manuals direct the researcher to divide the original weight variable by 1,000,000 before applying the weighting factor to the original DHS data files, it is not necessary to modify the value of PERWEIGHT before applying this weight to cases in IPUMS-DHS.
PERWEIGHT should be used to weight nearly all tabulations made using IPUMS-DHS data. Occasionally, as with the domestic violence variables, a subset of respondents are randomly selected to answer questions from a survey module, and a specialized weight such as DVWEIGHT should be used instead.
Note: The 6 implied decimal places in PERWEIGHT mean that the last six digits of the eight-digit variable are decimal digits, but there is no actual decimal in the data.
var.codInstr: PERWEIGHT is an 8-digit numeric variable with 6 implied decimal places. See the variable description for directions on the use of PERWEIGHT.
var.concept: Weights and subsample selection Variables -- PERSON

var.name: AWFACTT
var.labl: All woman factor for total population
var.txt:
AWFACTT is a 5-digit variable (in IPUMS-DHS) with 2 implied decimal places that is used to create total population estimates for all women of childbearing age, for those samples interviewing only ever-married women. A post from DHS senior staff member Tom Pullum on the DHS Users Forum explains, The all-woman factors are needed when you are trying to estimate something for all women, but you have to work with ever-married women because that's all you have in the sample. An example is when you want to estimate a fertility rate for all women but you only have the births and exposure for ever-married women. You have to assume that (a) never-married women have no births and (b) awfact/100 is a multiplier to inflate exposure for ever-married women to exposure for all women.
For surveys that used a sampling frame of all women of childbearing age, AWFACTT has a value of 100 (or 1.00, with two decimal places), and thus has no effect on the survey statistics when used as a multiplier. For samples that included only ever-married women, AWFACTT serves as a multiplier to create total population figures for all women of childbearing age, following the assumptions noted above.
The width of AWFACTT ranges from a low of 3 to a high of 5 in the original DHS files; see Comparability for further discussion.
var.codInstr: AWFACTT is a 5-digit numeric variable with 2 implied decimal places. See the variable description for directions on the use of AWFACTT.
var.concept: Weights and subsample selection Variables -- PERSON

var.name: AWFACTU
var.labl: All woman factor for urban versus rural population
var.txt:
AWFACTU is a 5-digit variable (in IPUMS-DHS) with 2 implied decimal places that is used to create total population estimates by urban versus rural residence for all women of childbearing age, for those samples interviewing only ever-married women.
A post from DHS senior staff member Tom Pullum on the DHS Users Forum explains the use of the AWFACT adjustment variables as follows: The all-woman factors are needed when you are trying to estimate something for all women, but you have to work with ever-married women because that's all you have in the sample. An example is when you want to estimate a fertility rate for all women but you only have the births and exposure for ever-married women. You have to assume that (a) never-married women have no births and (b) awfact/100 is a multiplier to inflate exposure for ever-married women to exposure for all women.For surveys that used a sampling frame of all women of childbearing age, AWFACTU has a value of 100 (or 1.00, with two decimal places), and thus has no effect on the survey statistics when used as a multiplier. For samples that included only ever-married women, AWFACTU serves as a multiplier to create total population figures, by urban versus rural location, for all women of childbearing age, following the assumptions noted above.
The width of AWFACTU ranges from a low of 3 to a high of 5 in the original DHS files; see Comparability for further discussion.
var.codInstr: AWFACTU is a 5-digit numeric variable with 2 implied decimal places. See the variable description for directions on the use of AWFACTU.
var.concept: Weights and subsample selection Variables -- PERSON

var.name: AWFACTR
var.labl: All woman factor for population by region
var.txt:
AWFACTR is a 5-digit variable (in IPUMS-DHS) with 2 implied decimal places that is used to create total population estimates by region for all women of childbearing age, for those samples interviewing only ever-married women.
A post from DHS senior staff member Tom Pullum on the DHS Users Forum explains the use of the AWFACT adjustment variables as follows: The all-woman factors are needed when you are trying to estimate something for all women, but you have to work with ever-married women because that's all you have in the sample. An example is when you want to estimate a fertility rate for all women but you only have the births and exposure for ever-married women. You have to assume that (a) never-married women have no births and (b) awfact/100 is a multiplier to inflate exposure for ever-married women to exposure for all women.For surveys that used a sampling frame of all women of childbearing age, AWFACTR has a value of 100 (or 1.00, with two decimal places), and thus has no effect on the survey statistics when used as a multiplier. For samples that included only ever-married women, AWFACTR serves as a multiplier to create total population figures, by region, for all women of childbearing age, following the assumptions noted above.
The width of AWFACTR ranges from a low of 3 to a high of 5 in the original DHS files; see Comparability for further discussion.
var.codInstr: AWFACTR is a 5-digit numeric variable with 2 implied decimal places. See the variable description for directions on the use of AWFACTR.
var.concept: Weights and subsample selection Variables -- PERSON

var.name: AWFACTE
var.labl: All women factor for population by education
var.txt:
AWFACTE is a 5-digit variable (in IPUMS-DHS) with 2 implied decimal places that is used to create total population estimates by education for all women of childbearing age, for those samples interviewing only ever-married women.
A post from DHS senior staff member Tom Pullum on the DHS Users Forum explains the use of the AWFACT adjustment variables as follows: The all-woman factors are needed when you are trying to estimate something for all women, but you have to work with ever-married women because that's all you have in the sample. An example is when you want to estimate a fertility rate for all women but you only have the births and exposure for ever-married women. You have to assume that (a) never-married women have no births and (b) awfact/100 is a multiplier to inflate exposure for ever-married women to exposure for all women.For surveys that used a sampling frame of all women of childbearing age, AWFACTE has a value of 100 (or 1.00, with two decimal places), and thus has no effect on the survey statistics when used as a multiplier. For samples that included only ever-married women, AWFACTE serves as a multiplier to create total population figures, by education, for all women of childbearing age, following the assumptions noted above.
The width of AWFACTE ranges from a low of 3 to a high of 5 in the original DHS files; see Comparability for further discussion.
var.codInstr: AWFACTE is a 5-digit numeric variable with 2 implied decimal places. See the variable description for directions on the use of AWFACTE.
var.concept: Weights and subsample selection Variables -- PERSON

var.name: AWFACTW
var.labl: All women factor for population by wealth index
var.txt:
AWFACTW is a 5-digit variable (in IPUMS-DHS) with 2 implied decimal places that is used to create total population estimates by relative wealth of the household for all women of childbearing age, for those samples interviewing only ever-married women.
A post from DHS senior staff member Tom Pullum on the DHS Users Forum explains the use of the AWFACT adjustment variables as follows: The all-woman factors are needed when you are trying to estimate something for all women, but you have to work with ever-married women because that's all you have in the sample. An example is when you want to estimate a fertility rate for all women but you only have the births and exposure for ever-married women. You have to assume that (a) never-married women have no births and (b) awfact/100 is a multiplier to inflate exposure for ever-married women to exposure for all women.For surveys that used a sampling frame of all women of childbearing age, AWFACTW has a value of 100 (or 1.00, with two decimal places), and thus has no effect on the survey statistics when used as a multiplier. For samples that included only ever-married women, AWFACTW serves as a multiplier to create total population figures, by wealth index, for all women of childbearing age, following the assumptions noted above.
The width of AWFACTW ranges from a low of 3 to a high of 5 in the original DHS files; see Comparability for further discussion.
var.codInstr: AWFACTW is a 5-digit numeric variable with 2 implied decimal places. See the variable description for directions on the use of AWFACTW.
var.concept: Weights and subsample selection Variables -- PERSON

var.name: DVWEIGHT
var.labl: Weight for domestic violence module
var.txt:
DVWEIGHT (D005) is an 8-digit variable with 6 implied decimal places, which should be used as a weighting factor for the subset of women who were randomly selected and interviewed in privacy for the domestic violence module (as indicated by DVMODULE) (V044). For further information about using weights with the DHS data, see PERWEIGHT (V005).
Note: The 6 implied decimal places in DVWEIGHT mean that the last six digits of the eight-digit variable are decimal digits, but there is no actual decimal in the data.
var.codInstr: DVWEIGHT is an 8-digit numeric variable with 6 implied decimal places.
var.concept: Weights and subsample selection Variables -- PERSON

var.name: URBAN
var.labl: Urban-rural status
var.txt: URBAN (V025) indicates whether the person's de facto residence was in an urban or rural location. The definition of urban varies across countries. See Comparability.

var.name: GEO_IA1992_2015
var.labl: India regions, 1992 and 2015 [integrated; GIS]
var.txt:
GEO_IA1992_2015 indicates the region of India where the respondent was interviewed. The variable is integrated to yield units with consistent boundaries across samples.
Labels identify the modern geographic units (states) contained in each integrated region. Each sample also has its own non-integrated geography variable. The 2015 sample has greater geographic detail available in GEOALT_IA2015.
An integrated GIS map (in shapefile format) for India can be downloaded here.

catgry.labl: Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, Andaman and Nicobar Islands
Gujarat, Dadra and Nagar Haveli, Daman and Diu

var.name: GEO_IA2015
var.labl: India regions, 2015 [GIS]
var.txt:
GEO_IA2015 (V101_IA2015) indicates the region of India where the respondent was interviewed. DHS units in the 2015 India survey are equivalent to states, with the capital as its own region.
Other sample years have their own sample-specific geography variables. There is also an integrated variable, GEO_IA1992_2015, that provides spatially consistent units over time. Greater geographic detail for the 2015 India sample can be found in GEOALT_IA2015 (districts).
A GIS map for GEO_IA2015 (in shapefile format) can be downloaded from the DHS Program Spatial Data Repository Boundaries page.

var.name: GEOALT_IA2015
var.labl: India districts, 2015 [GIS]
var.txt:
GEOALT_IA2015 indicates the district in India where the respondent was interviewed. Districts are second administrative level of geography.
Other sample years have their own sample-specific geography variables. There is also an integrated variable, GEO_IA1992_2015, that provides spatially consistent units over time with less geographic detail (states). The first administrative level of geography, states, can be found in GEO_IA2015.
A GIS map for GEOALT_IA2015 (in shapefile format) can be downloaded from the DHS Program Spatial Data Repository Boundaries page.

var.name: AGE
var.labl: Age
var.txt: AGE (V012) reports the woman's age. DHS surveys collect information about the woman's age through questions about age at last birthday and date of birth. DHS Recode Manuals provide the following information about how the AGE variable is calculated: Current age in completed years is calculated from the century month code of the date of birth of the respondent (V011) and the century month code of the date of interview (V008). In a few cases the age in the data file will be different from that reported by the respondent when the respondent's birthday was in the month of interview, but she had not yet had her birthday. If the respondent correctly reported her age at her last birthday (and not her age at her next birthday) then the calculated age was rounded up from the reported age, to avoid inconsistencies between the age and the century month code for the birth.

var.name: AGE5YEAR
var.labl: Age in 5 year groups
var.txt: AGE5YEAR (V013) reports the woman's age in 5-year groups, based on data from the AGE (V012) variable. The age range of women interviewed varies across samples. See Comparability.

var.name: BIRTHMO
var.labl: Woman's month of birth
var.txt: BIRTHMO (V009) reports the woman's month of birth.

var.name: BIRTHYEAR
var.labl: Woman's year of birth
var.txt: BIRTHYEAR (V010) reports the woman's year of birth.

var.name: DOBCMC
var.labl: Respondent's date of birth, in century months
var.txt:
DOBCMC (V011) reports the century month code (CMC) for the woman's date of birth.
Century month codes (CMC) are particularly useful for checking the consistency of dates, calculating intervals between events, and imputing dates when the information for an event is missing or partially complete.
Century month codes (CMC) are calculated by multiplying by 12 the difference between the year of an event and 1900. The year 1900 was chosen as the reference period because all of the DHS-relevant events occurred during the twentieth or twenty-first centuries. The month of the event is added to the previous result. CMC = (Year minus 1900) * 12 + MonthFor example, the CMC for June 2002 is: CMC = (2002 minus 1900) * 12 + 6 = 1230In other words, 1,230 months have elapsed between January 1900 and June 2002. Starting with CMC figures, one can calculate the month and year using the following formulas: Year = int( ( CMC minus 1 )/12 ) + 1900[int(x) is the integer part of x]Month = CMC minus ( ( Year minus 1900 ) * 12 )For more information, visit The DHS Program website to find the latest Guide to DHS Statistics.

var.name: DOBINFORESP
var.labl: Information given on respondent's date of birth
var.txt: DOBINFORESP (V014) reports the completeness of information about the respondent's age and date of birth. A code of 0 indicates the month and the year were reported, and no data were imputed.

catgry.labl: Year only, age and month imputed
Age only, year and month imputed
Month only, age and year imputed

var.name: RESIDENT
var.labl: Usual resident or visitor
var.txt: RESIDENT (V135) indicates whether the woman was a usual resident of the household or was just visiting there. As defined by the RESIDENT variable, a visitor could potentially reside in the city, town, or village where the interview took place but would have answered "No" to the question, "Does (NAME) usually live here [in this dwelling unit]?" on the household questionnaire.

var.name: RELATE
var.labl: Respondent's relationship to HH head
var.txt: RELATE (V150) reports the woman's relationship to the head of the household, based on a question in the household questionnaire.

var.name: PREGNANT
var.labl: Currently pregnant
var.txt: PREGNANT (V213) indicates whether the respondent is currently pregnant.

var.name: DURCURPREG
var.labl: Duration of current pregnancy
var.txt: For currently pregnant women, DURCURPREG (V214) reports the imputed duration of the woman's current pregnancy.

var.name: TRIPAWAY1MO
var.labl: Respondent away from home for over 1 month in last year
var.txt: TRIPAWAY1MO (V168) indicates whether the respondent has been away from home or from her home community for more than one month at a time in the last 12 months.

var.name: TRIPAWAY6MO
var.labl: Respondent away from home for over 6 months in last year
var.txt: TRIPAWAY6MO indicates whether the respondent has been away from home or from her parents' or in-laws' home for more than six months at a time in the last year.

var.name: RELIGION
var.labl: Religion
var.txt: RELIGION (V130) reports the respondent's religion. While the categories and codes for the religion variable in the original DHS files are country-specific, IPUMS-DHS uses a 4-digit composite coding system to fit these diverse categories into a single variable without losing information. See Comparability.

var.name: ETHNICITYIA
var.labl: Ethnicity, India
var.txt: ETHNICITYIA (V131IA) is a variable specific to India that reports the woman's ethnicity in broad categories for caste or tribe. Responses to ETHNICITYIA change over time. See Comparability.

var.name: MARSTAT
var.labl: Woman's current marital or union status
var.txt: MARSTAT (V501) reports the woman's current marital status. Response categories and question wording vary across surveys. See Comparability.

var.name: CHEB
var.labl: Total children ever born
var.txt:
CHEB (V201) reports the total number of children ever born to the respondent. The number reported in CHEB is the sum of a series of variables covering the total number of sons and daughters who are living at home, living away from home, or who have died (V202 to V207).
The number of births reported in CHEB will match the number of entries in the birth history (V224) for up to 20 births. If the woman reported more than 20 births, then the number for CHEB will exceed the number of births in the birth history, but such cases are rare.

var.name: TOTBIRTHIST
var.labl: Number of entries in the birth history
var.txt:
TOTBIRTHIST (V224) reports the number of entries in the woman respondent's birth history.
For up to 20 births, the birth history contains information for each of the respondent's births. In those rare cases when the respondent had more than 20 births, the birth history lists the last 19 births and the first birth.
In cases where the women had fewer than 20 births, the number reported in TOTBIRTHIST will match the number reported in CHEB (V201), the total number of children ever born to the respondent.

var.name: SONSATHOME
var.labl: Number of own sons living at home
var.txt:
SONSATHOME (V202) reports the number of sons to whom the woman has given birth who are currently living with her.
The related variable SONSAWAYHOME (V204) reports the number of sons to whom the woman has given birth and are still alive, but who are not currently living with her.

var.name: DAUSATHOME
var.labl: Number of own daughters living at home
var.txt:
DAUSATHOME (V203) reports the number of daughters to whom the woman has given birth who are currently living with her.
The related variable DAUSAWAYHOME (V205) reports the number of daughters to whom the woman has given birth and are still alive, but who are not currently living with her.

var.name: SONSAWAYHOME
var.labl: Number of own sons living away from home
var.txt:
SONSAWAYHOME (V204) reports the number of sons to whom the woman has given birth who are still alive, but who are not currently living with her.
The related variable SONSATHOME (V202) reports the number of sons to whom the woman has given birth who are still alive, and who are currently living with her.

var.name: DAUSAWAYHOME
var.labl: Number of own daughters living away from home
var.txt:
DAUSAWAYHOME (V205) reports the number of daughters to whom the woman has given birth who are still alive, but who are not currently living with her.
The related variable DAUSATHOME (V203) reports the number of daughters to whom the woman has given birth who are still alive, and who are currently living with her.

var.name: SONSDIED
var.labl: Number of own sons who have died
var.txt: SONSDIED (V206) reports the number of sons to whom the woman has given birth who have died.

var.name: DAUSDIED
var.labl: Number of own daughters who have died
var.txt: DAUSDIED (V207) reports the number of daughters to whom the woman has given birth who have died.

var.name: BIRTHSIN5YRS
var.labl: Number of births in last 5 years
var.txt: BIRTHSIN5YRS (V208) reports the number of births the woman had in the five years prior to the survey. This statistic is calculated based on the total number of births in the 0 to 59 months prior to the month of the interview.

var.name: BIRTHSIN1YR
var.labl: Number of births in the past year
var.txt: BIRTHSIN1YR (V209) reports the number of births the woman had in the year prior to the survey. This statistic is calculated based on the total number of births in the months 0 to 12 (not 0 to 11) prior to the month of the interview. For example, if the survey were given in January, BIRTHSIN1YR would report the number of births the woman had between the time of the survey and the previous January.

var.name: BIRTHSIN1MO
var.labl: Total number of births in month of interview
var.txt: BIRTHSIN1MO (V210) reports the total number of births the woman had in the month of interview.

var.name: DOB1STKIDCMC
var.labl: Date of respondent's first birth, in century months
var.txt:
DOB1STKIDCMC (V211) reports the century month code (CMC) for the date of the woman's first birth.
Century month codes (CMC) are particularly important to check consistency of dates, to calculate intervals between events, and to impute dates when the information for an event is missing or partially complete.
Century month codes (CMC) are calculated by multiplying by 12 the difference between the year of an event and 1900. That year was chosen as the reference period because all of the DHS relevant events occurred during the twentieth or twenty-first centuries. The month of the event is added to the previous result. CMC = (Year minus 1900) * 12 + MonthFor example, the CMC for June 2002 will be: CMC = (2002 minus 1900) * 12 + 6 = 1230In other words, 1,230 months have elapsed since January 1900 to June 2002. Based on CMC it is possible to calculate the month and year using the following formulas: Year = int( ( CMC minus 1 )/12 ) + 1900[int(x) is the integer part of x]Month = CMC minus ( ( Year minus 1900 ) * 12 )For more information, visit The DHS Program website to find the latest Guide to DHS Statistics.

var.name: TIMEMENSTRUATE
var.labl: Time since woman's last menstrual period
var.txt: TIMEMENSTRUATE (V215) reports the time passed since the woman's last menstrual period, in days, weeks, months, or years.

var.name: MENSTRUATE6WK
var.labl: Woman menstruated in last 6 weeks
var.txt: MENSTRUATE6WK (V216) indicates whether the woman menstruated in the 6 weeks prior to the interview, as calculated from TIMEMENSTRUATE (V215).

var.name: OVCYCLE
var.labl: When in cycle thinks pregnancy is most likely
var.txt: OVCYCLE (V217) suggests the woman's knowledge of the ovulatory cycle by reporting when she believes a woman has the greatest chance of becoming pregnant.

var.name: CHEBALIVE
var.labl: Total number of living children born to respondent
var.txt:
CHEBALIVE (V218) reports the total number of children ever born to the respondent who are currently living. The number reported in CHEBALIVE (V218) is the sum of a series of variables reporting the total number of sons and daughters who are living at home and who are living away from home (V202 to V205 - SONSATHOME, DAUSATHOME, SONSAWAYHOME, and DAUSAWAYHOME).
The related variable CHEB (V201) reports the total number of children ever born to the respondent, regardless of survival status.

var.name: CHSURVPLUSPG
var.labl: Total number of living children including current pregnancy
var.txt:
CHSURVPLUSPG (V219) reports the woman's total number of living children, including her current pregnancy.
CHSURVPLUSPG takes the value of CHEBALIVE (V218) and adds 1 if the respondent is pregnant.

var.name: CHEBALIVETRUNC
var.labl: Total number of living children, truncated at 6+
var.txt: CHEBALIVETRUNC (V220) reports the woman's total number of living children (including current pregnancy), truncated at 6 or more children. This variable is a grouping of CHSURVPLUSPG (V219) truncated at 6+ children.

var.name: LASTBIRTHTOINTMO
var.labl: Interval between last birth and interview, in months
var.txt: For women who have ever given birth, LASTBIRTHTOINTMO (V222) reports the number of months between their last birth and the date of interview.

var.name: CONCEPTDATEFLAG
var.labl: Completeness of information on date of conception, current pregnancy
var.txt:
For pregnant women, CONCEPTDATEFLAG (V223) indicates the completeness of information relating to the date of conception of their current pregnancy. According to the DHS Recode Manuals, "This variable indicates whether the date of conception was exactly specified by the duration of the current pregnancy or the duration was imputed from other information."
The related variable DURCURPREG reports the duration of the current pregnancy.

var.name: MENSTIMFLAG
var.labl: Flag for reported time since last menstrual period
var.txt:
MENSTIMFLAG (V227) is a flag variable that indicates the type of problem, if any, found in editing responses on the time since the respondent's last menstrual period. Cases without a problem are coded 0.
For time since last menstrual period, see TIMEMENSTRUATE (V215).

catgry.labl: Number reported, but period not returned
Reported before last birth, but no birth
Reported before last birth, but period since
Reported never menstruated, but period returned
Reported never menstruated but had kids

var.name: PREGTERMIN
var.labl: Ever had pregnancy terminate via abortion, miscarriage or stillbirth
var.txt: PREGTERMIN (V228) indicates whether the woman ever had a pregnancy that was terminated due to miscarriage, abortion, or stillbirth, and did not result in a live birth.

var.name: PREGTERMINMO
var.labl: Calendar month of pregnancy termination
var.txt: For women who have had a pregnancy terminated through abortion, stillbirth or miscarriage, PREGTERMINMO (V229) indicates the calendar month when the last pregnancy termination occurred, according to the Gregorian calendar.

var.name: PREGTERMINYR
var.labl: Year of last pregnancy termination
var.txt: For women who have had a pregnancy terminated through abortion, stillbirth or miscarriage, PREGTERMINYR (V230) reports the year when the last pregnancy termination occurred, according to the Gregorian calendar.

var.name: PREGTERMTIM
var.labl: Months pregnant when pregnancy terminated
var.txt: For women who had a pregnancy end without a live birth (through abortion, stillbirth or miscarriage) 5 years before the survey, PREGTERMTIM (V233) indicates how many months pregnant the woman was when the pregnancy ended.

var.name: PREGTERMPREV
var.labl: Respondent had previous pregnancy terminations (in last 5 years)
var.txt: For women who had a pregnancy end without a live birth (through abortion, stillbirth or miscarriage) (usually in the 5 years before the survey), PREGTERMPREV (V234) indicates whether the woman had any other pregnancies that ended without a live birth.

var.name: PRECALBIDX
var.labl: Birth history index for last child born prior to the start of the calendar
var.txt: PRECALBIDX (V235) provides the birth index number (see BIDX for more information) of the last child born to the woman before the start of the survey's birth calendar. For the majority of samples, PRECALBIDX reports the birth index number of the last child born prior to 5 years before the survey. For a minority of samples, the reference period is 3 or 4 years before the survey. See Sample Description information on the universes for children included in the surveys to learn the specific reference period for each survey.

var.name: BIRTHSOTHER
var.labl: Other live births in interval between last birth reported and date of interview
var.txt: BIRTHSOTHER (V237) indicates whether the woman had any other live births in the interval between the last reported birth and the date of the interview. The question for this variable verifies whether the woman omitted any births when reporting her birth record. Omitted births should be included in the final version of the birth history in the variable CHEB (V201).

var.name: BIRTHSTOT3YR
var.labl: Total births in last 3 years prior to interview
var.txt: BIRTHSTOT3YR (V238) indicates the total number of births the woman had in the 3 years (0 to 35 months) prior to the interview (where 0 is the month of interview). Responses are based on the woman's birth history table, which records the month and year of her children's births.

var.name: PRECALTERM
var.labl: Had pregnancies ending in miscarriage, abortion or stillbirth before calendar beginning
var.txt: PRECALTERM (V239) indicates whether the respondent had any pregnancies terminated through abortion, miscarriage or stillbirth prior to the survey's birth calendar.

var.name: PRECALTERMMO
var.labl: Month of last pregnancy termination prior to calendar
var.txt: For women who had any pregnancies terminated through abortion, miscarriage or stillbirth prior to the survey's birth calendar, PRECALTERMMO (V240) indicates the calendar month of the termination.

var.name: PRECALTERMYR
var.labl: Year of last pregnancy termination prior to calendar
var.txt: For women who had any pregnancies terminated through abortion, miscarriage or stillbirth prior to the survey's birth calendar, PRECALTERMYR (V241) indicates the calendar year of the termination.

var.name: PRECALTERMCMC
var.labl: Century month date of last pregnancy termination prior to calendar
var.txt:
For women who had any pregnancies terminated through abortion, miscarriage or stillbirth prior to the survey's birth calendar, PRECALTERMCMC (V242) reports the century month date of the last pregnancy termination before the start of the birth calendar.
For information on how to interpret and calculate century month dates, see DOBCMC.
All samples in PRECALTERMCMC use the Gregorian calendar. For similar data for Ethiopian samples using the Ethiopian calendar, see PRECALTERMCMC_ET.

var.name: PRECALTERMCOMP
var.labl: Completeness of information for last pregnancy termination prior to calendar
var.txt: For women who had any pregnancies terminated through abortion, miscarriage or stillbirth prior to the survey's birth calendar, PRECALTERMCOMP (V243) reports the completeness of information about the month and year of that pregnancy termination.

var.name: CALCOLNO
var.labl: Number of calendar columns
var.txt:
CALCOLNO (V019A) reports the number of columns of information from the longitudinal calendar data included in a women's (IR) sample. Retrospective calendar data for approximately five years before the survey interview, organized as person-months of exposure, include at least one column reporting whether a birth, pregnancy termination, pregnancy, contraceptive use, or none of these elements occurred during a particular month. Many samples include a second column documenting the reason for cessation of contraceptive use. Some samples include further columns covering such topics as union status, migration, and type of pregnancy termination.
Recode Manuals for DHS Phases IV to VI state, for variable V019A, "In the model B questionnaire [for low contraceptive prevalence countries] only 1 column is used and 4 columns in the model A questionnaire [for high contraceptive prevalence countries]." Countries did not always follow the practice of the standard questionnaires, however.

var.name: CALINTMOROW
var.labl: Row of calendar representing month of interview
var.txt:
The DHS Recode Manuals define CALINTMOROW (V018) as follows: "A Row of calendar representing the month of interview. The calendar is numbered from 1 to 80, with month 80 being January of the first year of the calendar."
Longitudinal calendar data, covering approximately five years before the survey interview, were organized as person-months of exposure and recorded the timing of pregnancies, pregnancy terminations, births, and contraceptive use.

var.name: CALLENGTH
var.labl: Length of calendar to use for this case
var.txt:
CALLENGTH (V019) reports "the length of the calendar for this case," according to the DHS Recode Manuals. Longitudinal calendar data, covering approximately five years before the survey interview, were organized as person-months of exposure and recorded the timing of pregnancies, pregnancy terminations, births, and contraceptive use inception and cessation.
According to the DHS Recode Manuals, V019 is equal to 80 minus V018 [the row of the calendar representing the month of interview] plus 1. "[For V018], the calendar is numbered from 1 to 80, with month 80 being January of the first year of the calendar."

var.name: CALSTARTCMC
var.labl: Century month code for start of calendar
var.txt:
The DHS Recode Manuals define CALSTARTCMC (V017) as follows: "Century month code for the first month of the calendar. This is constant for all cases and is the century month code of January of the first year of the calendar."
Longitudinal calendar data, covering approximately five years before the survey interview, were organized as person-months of exposure and recorded the timing of pregnancies, pregnancy terminations, births, and contraceptive use.
Century months express time as months since the start of the year 1900, according to the Gregorian calendar. For more information on how century months are calculated, see INTDATECMC (V008).

var.name: AGEMENARCHE
var.labl: Age at first period
var.txt: AGEMENARCHE reports the woman's age at the time of her first menstrual period.

var.name: MENSUSECLOTH
var.labl: Use cloth to protect against bloodstains during menstruation
var.txt: MENSUSECLOTH indicates whether the respondent uses cloth during menstruation to prevent bloodstains from becoming evident.

var.name: MENSUSELOCNAP
var.labl: Use locally prepared napkins to protect against bloodstains during menstruation
var.txt: MENSUSELOCNAP indicates whether the respondent uses locally prepared napkins during menstruation to prevent bloodstains from becoming evident.

var.name: MENSUSESANNAP
var.labl: Use sanitary napkins to protect against bloodstains during menstruation
var.txt: MENSUSESANNAP indicates whether the respondent uses sanitary napkins during menstruation to prevent bloodstains from becoming evident.

var.name: MENSUSETAMPON
var.labl: Use tampons to protect against bloodstains during menstruation
var.txt: MENSUSETAMPON indicates whether the respondent uses tampons during menstruation to prevent bloodstains from becoming evident.

var.name: MENSUSEOTHER
var.labl: Use other to protect against bloodstains during menstruation
var.txt: MENSUSEOTHER indicates whether the respondent uses some other product during menstruation to prevent bloodstains from becoming evident. The meaning of "other" depends on the specific forms of protection listed in a given survey.

var.name: MENSUSENONE
var.labl: Use nothing to protect against bloodstains during menstruation
var.txt: MENSUSENONE indicates whether the respondent uses nothing during menstruation to prevent bloodstains from becoming evident.

var.name: AGEAT1STBIRTH
var.labl: Age of respondent at time of first birth
var.txt:
AGEAT1STBIRTH (V212) reports the age of the woman at the time of her first birth. This variable is calculated by using the century month code (CMC) of the date of the woman's first birth (DOB1STKIDCMC) and the CMC of the woman's date of birth (DOBCMC).
Century month codes (CMC) are particularly useful for checking the consistency of dates, calculating intervals between events, and imputing dates when the information for an event is missing or partially complete.
Century month codes (CMC) are calculated by multiplying by 12 the difference between the year of an event and 1900. The year 1900 was chosen as the reference period because all of the DHS-relevant events occurred during the twentieth or twenty-first centuries. The month of the event is added to the previous result. CMC = (Year minus 1900) * 12 + MonthFor example, the CMC for June 2002 is: CMC = (2002 minus 1900) * 12 + 6 = 1230In other words, 1,230 months have elapsed between January 1900 and June 2002. Starting with CMC figures, one can calculate the month and year using the following formulas: Year = int( ( CMC minus 1 )/12 ) + 1900[int(x) is the integer part of x]Month = CMC minus ( ( Year minus 1900 ) * 12 )For more information, visit The DHS Program website to find the latest Guide to DHS Statistics.

var.name: PREGTERMCMC
var.labl: Century month date of last pregnancy termination
var.txt:
PREGTERMCMC (V231) reports the century month code of the respondent's last pregnancy termination, according to the Gregorian calendar.
According to the DHS Recode Manuals, "The CMC date of termination is calculated from the preceding questions [on month and year of last pregnancy termination], or from the calendar, if possible, in cases where an exact date was not given for the date of last pregnancy termination."
For detailed discussion of the calculation and interpretation of century month codes, see DOBCMC (Respondent's date of birth, in century months).

var.name: PREGTERMFLAG
var.labl: Date flag for last terminated pregnancy
var.txt: PREGTERMFLAG (V232) is a flag variable that indicates the type of information available on the date of the respondent's last terminated pregnancy. Survey forms supplied room to collect the month and year of the last terminated pregnancy, and cases for which both month and year are available are coded 1.

var.name: PREGTERMTYP
var.labl: Type of pregnancy termination
var.txt: PREGTERMTYP reports how the respondent's most recent pregnancy termination ended: as a stillbirth, miscarriage, abortion, or, in some samples, via "menstrual regulation" (see Comparability).

var.name: PREGTERMULTRA
var.labl: Had ultrasound before pregnancy termination
var.txt: PREGTERMULTRA indicates whether the respondent had an ultrasound during pregnancy, prior to the most recent pregnancy termination.

var.name: ABORTWHO
var.labl: Who performed respondent's most recent abortion
var.txt:
ABORTWHO reports who performed the respondent's most recent abortion.
The harmonized coding categories in the IPUMS-DHS variable ABORTWHO were constructed to reflect the major and minor categories in the original DHS variable. The major categories are:
10: Health professional
20: Other person The second digit of ABORTWHO's codes distinguish between specific individuals.

var.name: ABORTPLACE
var.labl: Place where most recent abortion was performed
var.txt:
ABORTPLACE reports the type of medical facility or other place (such as at home) where the respondent had her most recent abortion performed.
The harmonized coding categories in the IPUMS-DHS variable ABORTPLACE were constructed to reflect the major and minor categories in the original DHS variable. The major categories are:
1000: Public sector facilities
2000: Private medical sector facilities
3000: Non-governmental organizations (NGOs)
4000: Unspecified medical sector
5000: Other The second, third, and fourth digits of ABORTPLACE's codes distinguish between specific locations and provide additional detail, if available.

var.name: ABORTCOMP
var.labl: Had complications from most recent abortion
var.txt: ABORTCOMP indicates whether the respondent had complications from her most recent abortion.

var.name: ABORTCOMPTR
var.labl: Sought treatment for complications from most recent abortion
var.txt: ABORTCOMPTR indicates whether the respondent sought treatment for complications from her most recent abortion.

var.name: ABORTCOMPTRPLACE
var.labl: Place sought treatment for complications from most recent abortion
var.txt:
ABORTCOMPTRPLACE reports the type of medical facility or other place (such as at home) where the respondent sought treatment for complications from her most recent abortion.
The harmonized coding categories in the IPUMS-DHS variable ABORTCOMPTRPLACE were constructed to reflect the major and minor categories in the original DHS variable. The major categories are:
1000: Public sector facilities
2000: Private medical sector facilities
3000: Non-governmental organizations (NGOs)
4000: Other The second, third, and fourth digits of ABORTCOMPTRPLACE's codes distinguish between specific locations and provide additional detail, if available.

var.name: ABORTCOMPTRNOCOST
var.labl: Sought no treatment for abortion complications due to: Cost
var.txt: ABORTCOMPTRNOCOST indicates whether the respondent did not seek treatment for complications from her most recent abortion, because she could not afford treatment.

var.name: ABORTCOMPTRNOTRAN
var.labl: Sought no treatment for abortion complications due to: Lack transport
var.txt: ABORTCOMPTRNOTRAN indicates whether the respondent did not seek treatment for complications from her most recent abortion, because she could not afford transport.

var.name: ABORTCOMPTRNOSTIGP
var.labl: Sought no treatment for abortion complications due to: Stigma from provider
var.txt: ABORTCOMPTRNOSTIGP indicates whether the respondent did not seek treatment for complications from her most recent abortion, because of the fear of stigma by the provider.

var.name: ABORTCOMPTRNOSTIGC
var.labl: Sought no treatment for abortion complications due to: Stigma from community
var.txt: ABORTCOMPTRNOSTIGC indicates whether the respondent did not seek treatment for complications from her most recent abortion, because of the fear of stigma by the community.

var.name: ABORTCOMPTRNOMINOR
var.labl: Sought no treatment for abortion complications due to: Minor, no need
var.txt: ABORTCOMPTRNOMINOR indicates whether the respondent did not seek treatment for complications from her most recent abortion, because the complication was minor and did not require treatment.

var.name: ABORTCOMPTRNORESOLVE
var.labl: Sought no treatment for abortion complications due to: Resolved itself
var.txt: ABORTCOMPTRNORESOLVE indicates whether the respondent did not seek treatment for complications from her most recent abortion, because the problem resolved itself.

var.name: ABORTCOMPTRNOFAM
var.labl: Sought no treatment for abortion complications due to: Family duties
var.txt: ABORTCOMPTRNOFAM indicates whether the respondent did not seek treatment for complications from her most recent abortion, because she could not get away from family responsibilities.

var.name: ABORTCOMPTRNOPERMIT
var.labl: Sought no treatment for abortion complications due to: Lack permission
var.txt: ABORTCOMPTRNOPERMIT indicates whether the respondent did not seek treatment for complications from her most recent abortion, because her husband did not give permission.

var.name: ABORTCOMPTRNOTH
var.labl: Sought no treatment for abortion complications due to: Other
var.txt: ABORTCOMPTRNOTH indicates whether the respondent did not seek treatment for complications from her most recent abortion for some other reason. The meaning of other depends on the reasons specified in a given survey.

var.name: HYSTOPEV
var.labl: Ever had hysterectomy
var.txt: HYSTOPEV indicates whether the respondent ever had a hysterectomy (described as "an operation to remove the uterus").

var.name: HYSTOPYRAGO
var.labl: Years ago had hysterectomy
var.txt: HYSTOPYRAGO reports how many years ago the respondent had a hysterectomy, from within the past year (code 0) to up to 35 years ago.

var.name: HYSTOPPLACE
var.labl: Place where hysterectomy was performed
var.txt:
HYSTOPPLACE reports the type of medical facility where the respondent had a hysterectomy performed.
The harmonized coding categories in the IPUMS-DHS variable HYSTOPPLACE were constructed to reflect the major and minor categories in the original DHS variable. The major categories are:
100: Public sector facilities
200: Private medical sector facilities
300: Non-governmental organizations (NGOs)
The second and third digits of HYSTOPPLACE's codes distinguish between specific locations and provide additional detail, if available.

var.name: HYSTOPMENST
var.labl: Reason for hysterectomy: Menstrual bleeding or pain
var.txt: HYSTOPMENST indicates whether the respondent had a hysterectomy due to "excessive menstrual bleeding and/or pain."

var.name: HYSTOPCYST
var.labl: Reason for hysterectomy: Fibroids/cysts
var.txt: HYSTOPCYST indicates whether the respondent had a hysterectomy due to fibroids/cysts. Fibroids are (nearly always non-cancerous) uterine tumors. Women with fibroids may experience no or mild symptoms, or may experience serious symptoms such as heavy bleeding and pain.

var.name: HYSTOPRUPTURE
var.labl: Reason for hysterectomy: Uterine rupture
var.txt: HYSTOPRUPTURE indicates whether the respondent had a hysterectomy due to "uterine disorder (rupture)." Uterine rupture is a rare event in which the wall of the uterus tears, usually occurring during labor.

var.name: HYSTOPCANCER
var.labl: Reason for hysterectomy: Cancer
var.txt: HYSTOPCANCER indicates whether the respondent had a hysterectomy due to (uterine) cancer.

var.name: HYSTOPROLAPSE
var.labl: Reason for hysterectomy: Uterine prolapse
var.txt: HYSTOPROLAPSE indicates whether the respondent had a hysterectomy due to uterine prolapse. Uterine prolapse occurs when pelvic muscles or ligaments become weak, and the uterus slips from its normal position into the vagina.

var.name: HYSTOPPHEM
var.labl: Reason for hysterectomy: Severe post-partum hemorrhage
var.txt: HYSTOPPHEM indicates whether the respondent had a hysterectomy due a severe post-partum hemorrhage.

var.name: HYSTOPOTHER
var.labl: Reason for hysterectomy: Other reason
var.txt: HYSTOPOTHER indicates whether the respondent had a hysterectomy due to some other reason. The meaning of "other" depends on the reasons specified in a particular survey.

var.name: CURRWORK
var.labl: Currently working
var.txt: CURRWORK (V714) indicates whether the woman is currently working at a job or business. To distinguish employment from household labor, many surveys included a preface such as the following: "As you know, some women take up jobs for which they are paid in cash or in kind. Others sell things, have a small business or work on the family farm or in the family business." Women who have worked outside of their own housework in the last 12 months and been paid in cash, cash and in-kind, or only in-kind payments are included as working, although the survey questions vary in who receives an affirmative response. See Comparability.

var.name: WEALTHQ
var.labl: Household wealth index in quintiles
var.txt:
WEALTHQ (V190) refers to the relative wealth of the household where the woman lives, divided into quintiles from the poorest (code 1) to the richest (code 5). The wealth index is defined in the DHS Recode Manuals as follows: The wealth index is a composite measure of a household's cumulative living standard. The wealth index is calculated using easy-to-use data on a household's ownership of selected assets, such as televisions and bicycles; materials used for housing construction; and types of water access and sanitation facilities.Generated with a statistical procedure known as principal components analysis, the wealth index places individual households on a continuous scale of relative wealth. DHS separates all interviewed households into five quintiles of wealth.For additional information about the calculation and meaning of the wealth index, users should consult the summary information about the wealth index on The DHS Program website here and/or the DHS Comparative Report on "The DHS Wealth Index" here.
The complementary variable WEALTHS reports the wealth index factor score for the woman's household in a specific sample. WEALTHQ and WEALTHS are included on the woman's record for Phase 5 forward only. IPUMS-DHS has made available these variables for Phase 2 forward, by linking the wealth index files to the woman's individual recode files.
The variables used to calculate wealth index quintiles and the level of wealth implied by a specific ranking are sample-specific. See Comparability.

var.name: WEALTHS
var.labl: Wealth index factor score (5 decimals)
var.txt:
WEALTHS (V191) refers to the households wealth index value generated by the product of standardized scores (z-scores) and factor coefficient scores (factor loadings) of wealth indicators. Most researchers will want to use instead the complementary variable WEALTHQ (V190), which reports quintile ranking (from poorest to richest) of the woman's household, in terms of wealth score, for a given sample.
For further information about the calculation and meaning of the wealth index, see the description of WEALTHQ, the summary information about the wealth index on the DHS Program website here and/or the DHS Comparative Report on The DHS Wealth Index here.
The variables used to calculate wealth index scores are sample-specific. See Comparability.

var.name: EDUCLVL
var.labl: Highest educational level
var.txt:
For women who ever went to school, EDUCLVL (V106) reports the highest level of school they attended. Countries vary in the gradations of their school systems, but EDUCLVL is a standardized variable reporting level of education in four broad categories: No education, Primary, Secondary, and Higher.
The DHS recode manuals state, "In some countries the educational system does not fit naturally within this scheme, and a different categorization was used for the Final Report. In this case, this variable is constructed as accurately as possible from the country's own scheme, and the variable used for the Final Report is included as a country-specific variable."

var.name: EDYRTOTAL
var.labl: Total years education
var.txt: EDYRTOTAL (V133) reports the woman's education level in single years. This variable is constructed from responses to EDUCLVL (V106) and YRSCHL (V107) as follows: If EDUCLVL = "No education," EDYRTOTAL = "0"If EDUCLVL = "Primary," EDYRTOTAL = YRSCHLIf EDUCLVL = "Secondary," EDYRTOTAL = YRSCHL + xIf EDUCLVL = "Higher," EDYRTOTAL = YRSCHL + yIf EDUCLVL = "Missing," EDYRTOTAL = "Missing"In the above equations, "x" equals the number of years needed to complete primary education, and "y" equals the number of years needed to complete primary and secondary education. The values of "x" and "y" are country-specific.

var.name: KIDSEX
var.labl: Sex of child
var.txt: KIDSEX (B4) reports the sex of the child.

var.name: KIDALIVE
var.labl: Child is alive
var.txt: KIDALIVE (B5) reports whether the child was alive or dead at the time of interview.

var.name: KIDBIRTHMO
var.labl: Child's month of birth
var.txt: KIDBIRTHMO (B1) reports the child's month of birth, according to the Gregorian calendar.

var.name: KIDBIRTHYR
var.labl: Child's year of birth
var.txt: KIDBIRTHYR (B2) reports the child's year of birth, according to the Gregorian calendar.

var.name: KIDCURAGE
var.labl: Current age of child in years
var.txt: KIDCURAGE (B8) reports the current age of the child, in years, at the time of the survey.

var.name: KIDDOBCMC
var.labl: Child's date of birth (CMC)
var.txt:
KIDDOBCMC (B3) reports the century month code for the date of birth of the child.
Century month codes (CMC) are particularly useful for checking the consistency of dates, calculating intervals between events, and imputing dates when the information for an event is missing or partially complete.
Century month codes (CMC) are calculated by multiplying by 12 the difference between the year of an event and 1900. The year 1900 was chosen as the reference period because all of the DHS-relevant events occurred during the twentieth or twenty-first centuries. The month of the event is added to the previous result. CMC = (Year minus 1900) * 12 + MonthFor example, the CMC for June 2002 is: CMC = (2002 minus 1900) * 12 + 6 = 1230In other words, 1,230 months have elapsed between January 1900 and June 2002. Starting with CMC figures, one can calculate the month and year using the following formulas: Year = int( ( CMC minus 1 )/12 ) + 1900[int(x) is the integer part of x]Month = CMC minus ( ( Year minus 1900 ) * 12 )For more information, visit The DHS Program website to find the latest Guide to DHS Statistics.

var.name: KIDBORD
var.labl: Child's birth order number
var.txt: KIDBORD (BORD) reports the birth order in which the child was born, from 1 to n, where 1 = the first child born to a mother, and the nth birth is the most recently born child. Up to 20 births could be reported by a woman.

var.name: KIDTWIN
var.labl: Child is twin or single birth
var.txt: KIDTWIN (B0) reports whether the child is a twin (or born in a multiple birth) or is a single birth.

var.name: KIDAGEDEATH
var.labl: Child age at death (non-imputed)
var.txt: For deceased children, KIDAGEDEATH (B6) reports the age of the child at death in days, months or years. The first digit of the codes indicates the time unit: 1 for days, 2 for months, 3 for years.

catgry.labl: Days: Died on day of birth

var.name: KIDAGEDIEDIMP
var.labl: Child's age at death in month (including imputed)
var.txt: For deceased children, KIDAGEDIEDIMP (B7) reports the age of the child at death in months (including imputed ages).

var.name: KIDAGEDEATHFLAG
var.labl: Flags for reported age at death of child
var.txt: KIDAGEDEATHFLAG (B13) reports the type of problem, if any, found when editing responses about the child's age at death (in KIDAGEDEATH). A code of 0 indicates no problem with the original response.

catgry.labl: Reported age places death after interview
Reported age less than reported duration breastfeeding
Reported age less than age given supplemental food
Reported age less than age first breastfed
Reported age outside expected range for units
Reported age was imputed, units given
Reported age was imputed, units not given

var.name: KIDLIVESWITH
var.labl: Child lives with female respondent or with others
var.txt: KIDLIVESWITH (B9) reports the person the child usually lives with (i.e., the child's mother or someone else).

var.name: LINENOKID
var.labl: Line number of child in household
var.txt: LINENOKID (B16) reports the number of the line on which the DHS interviewer recorded the child's name, when filling out the household schedule. After asking the woman respondent, "Please give me the names of the persons who usually live in your household or are staying with you now, starting with the head of the household," the interviewer recorded each name in turn on successively numbered lines printed on the household survey form.

var.name: BIRTHINTPOSTMO
var.labl: Length of following birth interval, in months
var.txt: For children born in the three to five years preceding the survey who are not the last-born, or twin of the last-born, child, BIRTHINTPOSTMO (B12) indicates the succeeding birth interval, or the length of time in months the child was born before the mother's next birth (or before the child's first younger sibling).

var.name: OTHBIRTHININT
var.labl: Any other live births in interval between birth and previous reported birth
var.txt:
OTHBIRTHININT (B15) indicates whether there were any other live births in the interval between this birth and the previously reported birth. The survey form included the question, "Were there any other live births between (NAME OF PREVIOUS BIRTH) and (NAME), including any children who died?"
For DHS Phase III only, OTHBIRTHININT (B15) is limited to "Births for which the interval between the birth and the previously reported birth was four or more years (B14 =1)," according to the Recode Manuals. For later Phases, the universe is all second- and higher-order births.
The DHS Recode Manuals include the following explanatory note about this variable: Variables B14 and B15 are questions used in the interview to try and ascertain if the respondent had omitted any live births while reporting her birth history. The birth history may have been modified during the interviewing process, and the responses may not now correspond to the interval between the birth and the preceding birth recorded in this section. The data have been included to help indicate cases where the respondent may have omitted live births while originally reporting the birth history. The omitted births should be included in this final version of the birth history.
